title: Implement basic IO primitives for the interpreter (putStrLn, getLine)
body:
Add IO primitive support to the GRIN interpreter so we can run `main = putStrLn \"Hello\"`.

**Deliverables:**
- Built-in function registry for primitive operations
- Implement IO primitives:
  - `putStrLn :: String -> IO ()` — print string + newline to stdout
  - `putStr :: String -> IO ()` — print string to stdout
  - `getLine :: IO String` — read a line from stdin
  - `return :: a -> IO a` — wrap value in IO
  - `(>>=) :: IO a -> (a -> IO b) -> IO b` — IO bind
- IO is modelled as a special GRIN function that performs side effects
- Unit/integration test: evaluate `main = putStrLn "Hello"` end-to-end and capture stdout

**Design notes:**
- IO in GRIN is typically modelled via a `RealWorld` token threaded through bind
- For the interpreter, we can simply perform the side effect when we encounter an IO primitive
- This is the M1 milestone: compile and run `main = putStrLn "Hello"`
